Ottawa, January 2nd, 1929.

Sir,-

The Department understands that the St. Regis Village Indian Day School was recently broken into at night and several articles were stolen and debris left in the classroom. Please let me know, at once, what action you have taken to trace the guilty parties.

The Department considers that a Yale lock should be placed on the main door and a bolt on the inside of the inner door. Please arrange to secure these and place them in position at the earliest possible date.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. A. MacGibbon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.

Form No. 101
Sir:

In reply to your letter of Jan. 2nd. with reference to the St. Regis Village Indian Day School being broken into, I beg to say that this matter was reported to me the following day after this occurred. I took the matter up and endeavoured to find the guilty parties, but am unsuccessful so far. I have in mind that there is some Indian who has a number of keys, and that one of the keys duplicated the door lock on the school. The locks on the school door were not broken, so it is quite evident that the parties who entered the school, entered through the door by the use of a duplicate key.

Since this has happened, I have put on the doors of this school, one good yale night latch on one door, and an inside door bolt on the other, so I hope and trust that this school will not be interfered with in future.

I may say that I have had no complaints of the other schools on the reserve interfered with.

I am,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

St. Regis, Que.
March 23rd, 1929.

Sir:

With reference to attached Voucher #500 I beg to say that it was necessary that ten links of stove-pipes, in the junior room, St. Regis Village school, be replaced with new ones. There has been trouble with the chimney in this room leaking during the past six months. The liquid from the chimney running back into the stove-pipes, which causes them to rust and rot very quickly. I had John L. Thompson and also myself examine the chimney, and cannot discover any defect. But there must be some cause for this trouble.

These stove-pipes were purchased at Hogansburg, N.Y. as the crossing to Cornwall, Ont. is impassible.

I am,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Agent

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, April 19, 1929.

Sir:

I have to refer to that portion of your letter of the 10th instant, concerning the Indian Band in Council's request for the use of the St. Regis Village School one-half day a month for their meetings. The Department is desirous of assisting the Council in their deliberations as far as possible; but, as there would be considerable inconvenience to the school activity if permission were granted for the use of the school building, I hesitate to accede to the request. Even if the council meetings were held on Saturday afternoon, I am satisfied there would be considerable difficulty in arranging for a thorough cleaning. Further, the school desks, on account of their size, are not entirely suitable for seating the Council. You might let me know why the arrangement in the past is not satisfactory, i.e., the holding of the meetings at the residence of either Jake Day or Angus P. White.

You may explain to the Council that the Department wishes to assist them as far as possible and that we would like to see a suitable council hall erected. In the case of other Indian bands where councils assist in the conduct of reserve affairs, the Indians have willingly recommended the use of their capital funds for the erection of a council hall, to be used for regular meetings and other community purposes.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. A. MacGibbon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, P. Q.

Ottawa, June 20, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, relative to the varnishing of the floors of the St. Regis Village Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the department will approve of your arranging to have this work carried out during the coming summer holidays. The floors should be thoroughly scrubbed and dried before the varnish is applied. You should arrange for the purchase of the quantity of varnish required and for the labour in having the work done, and you should see that a satisfactory job is performed.

After this work has been completed, please obtain accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst., Deputy and Secretary.

W. A. MacGibbon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, P.Q.

Sir,

I beg to report that St. Regis village school shed was again broken into on the night of the 27th February, 1930. From all appearance the guilty party tried to force open the shed lock, but was unsuccessful. A file or hack-saw was used to saw the lock, to gain entrance.

A new lock was placed on the shed the following day. Up to the present, I have been unable to find a clue that would lead to the guilty party.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum.

The senior class-room of the St. Regis Village Indian Day School needs re-decorating.

A doz. pictures, ½ for each class-room, would brighten up the walls and make them more attractive.

There are some mud holes at the corners of this school, the pupils track the mud into the class-room. A few loads of gravel which can be easily laid down would be an improvement.

Inspector.
Ottawa, November 3, 1931.

Sir:

Mr. McCookin, who recently visited St. Regis, states that the senior classroom of the Village Indian Day School requires to be redecorated. In this connection I have to request that you will furnish an estimate of the cost of having the interior walls and also the ceiling, if so far required, repainted or falsomilled and the woodwork repainted. The cost should include labour and material. You should also state what arrangements you would recommend be made to have this work carried out.

The Inspector also recommends that a flag pole be erected near the school building. Please furnish an estimate of the cost of erecting a suitable flag pole, including the supplying of necessary wire and spikes. The flag pole should be of a suitable type, but it is not intended that any large expenditure be incurred in installing same.

The Inspector also states that there are some mud holes at the corner of the school and that the pupils track mud into the classroom. He recommends that few loads of gravel be laid down in order to overcome the present conditions. I have to request that you will arrange to have the gravel required supplied and levelled around the school building in order to fill in the mud holes near the building. You will, no doubt, be able to obtain the services of an Indian to haul and spread the gravel. When this work is completed to your satisfaction, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

The Department will place an order to supply for each classroom a set of Nelson's Pictures of Canadian History. These will be sent to you, and you should see that the teachers have them placed on the walls in the classrooms.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

It is presumed the price for the work will be the same as charged for drilling the well at the Agency. After the well has been drilled, you should arrange for the cribbing of same and for the purchase and installation of the necessary piping and pump; also to have the ground properly graded to prevent surface drainage from seeping into the well. You should see that a satisfactory job is completed at the lowest possible cost.

His idea is to put a little block about two inches by one inch and an inch thick under each desk foot to facilitate sweeping and moving the seats when needed for gymnastics. Sir,

I wish to advise that the ceiling of the Senior room of the St. Regis village school is badly in need of painting. The paint has peeled off in patches and gives a very bad appearance.

Sir:

I have been requested by the village teachers regarding prospects for a garage for their automobiles. I have secured an estimate of the material required for a two car garage as follows: size 18 x 18, walls, one ply clapboards, T & G roof covered with felt roofing material, two pairs of doors, with windows, sills to be set on stones, interior levelled up with gravel, at a cost of $140.00 (approximately) including tax.

I can secure ground for this garage from Peter P. White (and his mother) twenty five feet by fifty ft. same depth as the lot on which Teachers residence stands, which adjoins to the south.

This garage could be placed within the school grounds but as the land is low lying, and would be boggy during fall and spring, it would cost more to place the land in shape than to buy the land from White, whose land is high, and drains off quickly.

Including labour and some additional fencing expenses in connection with the proposed garage would amount to around $250.00.

December 26th 1936.

Sir:

With reference to your letter regarding the necessity of serving meals to the children attending at the schools on the Reservation.

This matter has been discussed with the several Teachers and it is agreed that it would be beneficial for the children if meals were served, particularly as regards the country schools where practically all the children carry their lunch with them. I am advised that most of the lunches consist of plain, home made bread, in the form of sandwiches, using sometimes fruit and fat, but short on either meat or fats.

It has been found that a supply of fresh milk cannot be depended upon, as it will be some time in the New Year before the cattle begin to freshen. I have secured prices of soups, by the case, from Chevrier Bros., wholesale grocers, of Cornwall Ont., and as most of the Teachers consider soup the most satisfactory and convenient meal to serve, also most filling for the children, I am estimating the costs on the basis of serving soups, but which could, if desirable changed to serving milk & cocoa, when a supply is available.

Ottawa, January 5, 1937.

Dear Sir:

The Department has carefully considered the contents of your letter of the 26th ultimo, with reference to serving meals to the children attending the schools in the St. Regis Agency.

You are aware of the relief at present being given and other assistance is also contemplated. In addition, our funds are quite limited. Under these circumstances, the Department is not prepared at the present time to authorize the expenditure that would be necessary to serve midday meals at the St. Regis Village, St. Regis Island and Cornwall Island West Indian Day Schools.

You may, however, arrange for supplying soup for the month of January only at the Chenail, Chetlain and Cornwall Island East Indian Day Schools. At the end of this month, you should obtain a report from each of the teachers of these three schools stating whether or not they found the serving of soup beneficial to the children, and if, as a result, the attendance during the month was more regular than usual.

When this report is received, it will be decided whether or not the serving of soup can be continued for the months of February and March.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mrs. Mrs. Washington,

Each school day from Jan. 11 to Jan. 29 inclusive soup was given to the school children during their noon lunch.

The children enjoyed it very much and each wanted more than I allowed them.

I think myself that it is a very good idea and I trust that the Dept. will continue supplying it during the months of Feb. & March. It is a good idea to supply different kinds—vegetable, pea & tomato.

It is more of a success than milk and cocoa were at the West End School when supplied there.

Yours truly,
Colin Chisholm,
Cornwall Island East S.
St.Regis, Quebec,
February 3rd, 1937.

Sir:

Further with reference to the serving of meals to the children attending the schools on the Reserve.

A quantity of soup, three kinds, was placed in the Cornwall Island est., Chenail and Chetlain schools.

According to verbal and notations on the attendance reports received from the Teachers, the additional food has proved beneficial to the children and has improved the average attendance during the winter month, although on account of the Influenza epidemic the month has not been a fair test. The Teachers state this extra food has really been required as the lunches carried by the children are not sufficient enough to provide proper nourishment.

The Chenail and Chetlain schools use 3 tins daily, Cornwall Island east using 5 tins. There will be soup on hand for a few days during February.

May I suggest that the serving of soups be continued during February and March inclusive of Cornwall Island west, school as I am informed by Miss Peters that the lunches of most of the children are not very abundant, principally bread and fat.

I would judge that conditions on St. Regis Island is somewhat better, considering that there are only a few families from there on relief.

I enclose a letter received from Mr. Colin Chisholm teacher of Cornwall Island, est., school.

Your obedient Servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa,

Yours truly,

R. A. Hesey,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter regarding the replacing of the double desks in the junior room of the St. Regis village school with single desks.

I have talked this matter over with the Teacher and it is considered advisable to make the suggested change so as to have all desks of a uniform design and with a view to securing the best of attention from the children to their studies.

I will be able to use the best of the displaced double desks in the Chetlain and especially, the Chenail (double desks now in use) school where additional desks are required due to increased attendance.

There will be required three rows of desks seating 10 children each, aged five to six, seven to eight, nine to eleven.

An additional front is required to complete a row of single seats, now in use, seating children ages nine to eleven.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

St. Regis Quebec,
September 11th, 1937.

Dear Sir,

May I refer to Estimates (school equipment) 1937-1938, with reference to stove replacements.

The stoves in the St. Regis village school, Senior & Junior room, are actually worn out; the fire bricks are burnt and broken away, and the encasing broken through in spots. The same applies to the St. Regis Island, Chenail and Cornwall Island, west, Indian Day schools.

I have been quoted prices (Snetzinger's Hardware, Cornwall Ontario) on a Furnacette heater, of cast iron construction, encased in polished steel, the cold air is drawn off the floor to circulate through the room. Fire box 12½" diameter, coal or wood, Height to top 41½", floor space 18" x 18", price $35.00 each. A good appearing stove, which should be a better heater than the ones at present in use and more economical on coal.

Although the stove in the Chetlain school is not in as bad a shape as the others, it is a Quebec heater style and could be replaced to advantage.

I would recommend this matter be given favorable consideration. The schools would be all set, in this regard, for a number of years.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.
Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letters of the 11th and 25th ultimo in connection with the schools in the St. Regis Agency.

In view of your recommendation, you may purchase new stoves for the two classrooms in the St. Regis Village School, also for the St. Regis Island, Chenail and Cornwall Island, West, Indian Day Schools. It is noted that the cost of each of these stoves will be $35.00.

Our funds are quite limited and, in view of the expenditure that will be incurred for the stoves, I regret that it will not be possible to authorize purchase of the desks for the Junior room at the St. Regis Village School this year.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I wish to advise that several minor repairs are required at the St. Regis village Indian Day school.

Several of the lockes etc on the doors leading to the vestibules and cloak rooms have become broken and should be replaced.

It would be a great improvement to have the older desks in the Junior room done over with a dark varnish stain. They are serviceable but have a worn appearance. About a dozen window glass to be replaced.

The children of the school appear to be hard on the outbuildings, they have become damaged and require repairing.

A new door and drop doors replaced, repairs to the tight board partition separating the buildings. It is proposed to have the buildings moved and fastened securely to the coal and woodshed, as a preventative against Hallowe'en tricks, etc.

An old unused well in close proximity to the school building requires to be planked as it is becoming unsafe.

The attached estimate gives approximate cost of repairs required.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

St. Regis March 15, 1939

Dear Sir,

School supplies

With reference to your letter of above date granting permission to purchase two covered water pails for use at the St. Regis Village Indian Day school.

What Miss McDonald had in mind in requisitioning for water pails was a covered cooler, or tank with a tap, which could be used by the children and avoid dipping their individual drinking cups into the pail.

I was able to secure only one, moderately priced cooler. It is large enough to do the two rooms; if not so, another one can be purchased later.

I would like to supply each school with a tank of the same style. A covered, heavy based, vacuum cooler with a tap. They would be much more sanitary than to allow each pupil to be dipping into a water pail.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

April 22nd., 1940

Dear Sir:

With further reference to our conversation on January 5th., last, regarding additional seating capacity in the schools, you will find attached requisition covering our requirements in this respect.

All prices quoted on requisition are those based on previous order supplied by Vilas Furniture Co., of Cowansville, Que., and may not be in force at the present time. However, there should not be any increase as prices quoted are those supplied for No. 2 desks, while the present order calls for No. 4 and No. 5 desks.

As you are no doubt aware there has been a considerable increase in the number of pupils attending the various schools. Ten additional seats will be required to take care of the Junior room requirements at the Village School. Eight additional desks are required at the Chenail School and about five at the St. Regis Island School.

It is our intention to place all the new desks in the Village school and transfer any seats that might be of further use to the other schools. In this way we can take care of the present additional pupils as well as the increased attendance which will take place at the opening of the new term and those pupils moving up to higher grades.

The fact that very few of our Indians have moved off the Reserve during the past few years has been a big factor in the increased attendance at the various schools. It is sincerely hoped that this requisition for desks will receive your kind consideration. I can assure you they are an absolute necessity.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir:

I have to refer to yours of July 30th., concerning appropriation for repairs and improvements at the days schools in this Agency.

With such a limited amount as stated in your letter I am doubtful as to the advisability of going ahead with any repairs. However I have enclosed a requisition covering materials required in order to shingle the village school. The labour of course is only an estimate, which may or may not be reduced by putting the job up for bid on a contract basis. On this latter point I recollect from conversation with Mr. McNaughton last year, working on a contract basis is not practiced by the Branch with Indian labour. It is offered only as a possible solution to decreasing labour costs. Consideration must be given however to obtaining labour that will do the work properly. We are not blessed with an abundance of such labour at this time.

You will note that the latter part of the requisition deals with scaffolding materials which are required if the job is to be done with consideration to the workmen. These materials should be kept here after the job for like purposes.

I would ask that you give this matter serious consideration as there is no question about the necessity of having this work done. There is an equally important job to be done at the Cornwall Ild. West school where the plaster has been falling off the walls in both cloak rooms for some time but as this is interior work it could be held over until next spring when new monies are voted.

Philip Phelan, Esq.,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch, OTTAWA.

St. Regis, Que.
October 16th., 1941.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to yours of the 4th., re shingling of St. Regis Village School.

Mr. Keddy has advised that he would be unable to do the work and we are therefore using Indian labour throughout. It was possible to obtain the services of one of our Cornwall Island Indians who is familiar with that kind of work and he has been placed in charge of the work which is being done by day labour. The job is progressing satisfactorily.

It would be appreciated if you would forward us an advance of $125.00 to take care of the labour in this connection. Any money that might be left over would be returned upon completion of the work. It is felt that it would be in the best interests if the workmen could be paid upon completion of the work.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Vouchers Nos. I96 & I97

With regard to the above vouchers please be advised that when an estimate for the cost of this work was put in, sufficient allowance was not made for additional expenditures which were encountered. Repairing the fence at the village school entailed considerably more labour than was at first thought as the fence was in a bad state of repair with many posts needing replacing and a general tightening up all around.

In addition the school toilets were cleaned out and the stove repaired at the Teachers' residence the fire-box having become broken through.

The cement platform at the Chenail school pump was in a dangerous state and while we had help available a new cement platform was constructed there. It was also necessary to replace thirty-five broken window panes at the village school which were broken by young rowdys.

In general repairs are now in a pretty fair state at the schools. I would recommend payment of the above vouchers at the earliest possible date as it makes it pretty difficult to get any help here when the labourers cannot get their pay at the close of a job.

Your obedient servant,

St. Regis, Que.
November 6th, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I wish at this time to bring to your attention an opportunity which has arisen whereby we would be in a position to fulfill our needs for school desks at the Village School (Jr. and Sr. room), Cornwall Island West and Chetlain Schools. The desks in question can be supplied by the Rev. rather Jacobs, local missionary at a price of $1.25 f.o.b. St. Regis, Que. per desk. In this connection it would be well to contact Inspector Thibault who is in a position to give you more detailed information.

I might say that the desks have been examined and although they are not new they are in good condition and are all single desks. The price asked is most reasonable.

At the present time we are in a position where we have not seating accommodation for our children and many have had to be sent home for this reason. This being due to more children coming of school age as well as other families returning to the reserve.

If we could be permitted to take advantage of this offer and buy 63 desks we would be in a position to fill our needs at the Village School as well as Cornwall Island and it would give us a chance to clean the Chetlain School out of double desks and put in all singles. In turn, we could use the desks from the Chetlain to fill our needs at the Chenail and St. Regis Island Schools where additions as well as replacements are needed. Apart from the initial cost of the desks a sum of approximately $35.00 would be required to cover transportation of the desks to the various schools as well as labour in setting them up.

I would recommend the above for your kind and early consideration as it may be sometime again before we could get a buy of this nature. You will recall that although new, the last seats purchased cost us $8.40 each.

Philip Phelan, Esq.,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Can.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Vouchers 296 & 297

The above represent expenditures required in connection with purchase of heater for use of the Sr. Room St. Regis Village Day School.

Purchase of heater for classroom was necessary due to the fact the fire box in the old stove had become broken through and was beyond repair and considered dangerous for further use.

While an effort was made to purchase a new heater at a reasonable price, this was not possible as none were available so the only alternative was to buy a rebuilt stove or discontinue the class for an indefinite period pending arrival of a suitable heater. The rebuilt heater purchased is a No. 5 and will serve our needs.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

At the beginning of each school term and sometimes during the term it has been found necessary to have the window panes replaced in the main doors at the Village school. Over thirty small panes had to be replaced so far this year.

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,

Re - Renovations, village schools
and Teacher's Residence.

Enclosed please find requisitions covering materials and approximate costs of painting the exterior of the St. Regis Village Indian Day school and St. Regis village school Teachers' Residence. I am also enclosing costs of material and labour expenditure covering the painting of the Cornwall Island, East, Indian Day school.

Regarding the Cornwall Island school, an Indian, of Cornwall Island has agreed to paint the buildings at .40¢ per hour. The buildings will possibly require two coats. If one is sufficient I can cut the costs in this connection.

I have been unable to find Indian labour who would agree to undertake the painting of the village school and Teachers' residence. In consequence I have submitted the names of two professional painters of Cornwall Ontario who have verbally advised me they would consider tendering.

It would be best to have them to supply material etc and labour.

In conclusion I wish to recommend that the proposed paint jobs be carried out, but if for any reason you wish to not authorize expenditure for all three jobs, I would stress that the village school should be painted this year.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, July 9, 1943.

Mr. D. P. McNaughton, Indian Agent, St. Regis, Que.

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant, the funds at our disposal will not permit authorizing the painting of the exterior of the St. Regis Village teachers' residence. However, in view of your recommendation, we approve the painting of the St. Regis Village School and we are requesting the Purchasing Branch to secure the material required.

It is noted from your letter that Indian labour is not available for this work, and we will advise you later who should be employed.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

I have to refer to your letter of July 31, regarding the Sisters of Ste. Anne taking charge of the St. Regis Village Day School. In this connection may I advise you that the Reverend Father Jacobs informs me that he has received notice of acceptance from the Mother General of the above order. It also appears that the Sisters who will take charge of the Village School will arrive in advance of the opening date of the school.

It would seem advisable, without delay, to consider cleaning of the interior of the residence to the extent at least of having the building in a state of cleanliness when the Sisters arrive. As the walls, with the exceptions of the kitchen and bathroom which are painted, are all kalsomined it would not be advisable at this time to consider decorating as the colour scheme we might choose would perhaps not be acceptable. I would, however, recommend that authorization be granted to hire some women to wash the kitchen and bath walls, woodwork and floors and give the place a general dusting down to remove cobwebs and the like. Consideration will also have to be given to repairs to the roof and around the windows where rain is continually seeping in and destroying the interior of the building. Some broken windows will need repairing as well.

I would suggest that, if you wish the above work be carried out, you wire me C.N.R. Cornwall as Mr. McNaughton is at present on vacation, our time is limited, the mail service poor and I have much pressing work in the field and may not be in the office should you decide to telephone.

Ottawa,
June 5, 1944.

Mr. T.L. Bonnah, Indian Agent, St. Regis, Que.

With reference to previous correspondence regarding the plan to be followed to secure water for the teachers' residence at St. Regis, I understand that Mr. Doucet discussed this with you on the occasion of his recent visit. Under these circumstances I trust that the attached sketch will make the plan clear. Mr. Doucet has drawn the diagram and also given a list of the materials required. You will note that 181' of piping will be needed. It will be necessary to have at least 2 pieces 10' long, 1 piece 5' long, 2 pieces 1' long and 1 piece 6' long. The remaining quantity of piping, to bring the total to 181', may be in any length that it is possible to secure.

The major portion of the work will be digging the trench from the well to the side of the residence. This pipe line should be connected to the existing pump, as it is not possible at the present time to obtain a gasoline engine of any kind.

It is felt that the total expenditure for material and labour should not exceed $150.

If there is any other information you require please let me know.

R.A. Hoey,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR J. THIBAULT,
dated June 7, 1945, on:-

ST. REGIS VILLAGE SCHOOL

This school is situated in the lowest part of the village and below river level. The junior classroom has sufficient space, but the senior class is altogether too small. No basement is possible on this location. Inside decorating is badly needed and plaster work requires repairs.
Ottawa, June 28, 1945.

Mr. T. L. Bonnah, Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.

Inspector Thibault has submitted a report regarding the St. Regis Village School.

As stated in my other letter of today's date, it is not possible to erect a new building this year. However, the inside of the school might be redecorated to make it more cheerful for the children. Please obtain a quotation on this work. I may say that we have available, in our current year's appropriation, $600.00 for repairs and improvements to the day schools in the St. Regis Agency, and I will be glad to have you give consideration to the best manner in which this amount can be expended.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of May 11th, I might say that we have a variety of repairs that could be undertaken at our schools and teachers' residences. I feel, however, that in spending such a small amount of money that is allotted for such a purpose this year many things will have to be considered. If a post war construction program is contemplated in this regard then the only thing we can do is try and hold the older buildings together by undertaking only extremely urgent repairs and spend the larger amount on the buildings you definitely know will be of use in future years.

Due to the nature of repairs in some instances it is virtually impossible to requisition the needed materials and in some cases it is not possible at this writing to even obtain certain materials.

We are up against a big job at the teachers' residence in the village as here we have plastered walls and the series of smaller tremors following last September's jolt has left the walls in a bad state. After interviewing a reputable contractor in Cornwall I am of the opinion there is little to be gained by going to the heavy expense of a replaster job in this building, as in most cases all plaster has to be removed. He suggested that I use V-lap (which is a sort of beaver board) and put this over the present plaster. At some future date should the V-lap become soiled it could be sized and painted. In this way we would eliminate the mess of a plaster job. I have seen some of this work done and it makes a good finish for a wall. The cost of this material is $77.00 per M.

As the sun room in the residence is in bad shape I thought, if agreeable to you, I would finish this room with V-lap and if it is satisfactory to all concerned we could consider at some future date finishing other rooms in a similar way.

p.t.o.
As it is impossible, with the limited funds available, to undertake extensive repairs at any one place I would offer the suggestion that an amount of $200.00 be advanced for labour costs and that permission be granted to obtain materials for extremely urgent repairs at the various schools and residences. It is understood, of course, that every possible precaution will be taken to keep the entire expenditure within the $500.00 mark.

Your early reply would be appreciated.

T. L. Connah
Indian Agent
Ottawa, June 27, 1945.

Mr. T. L. Bonnah, Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.

I have your letter of the 15th instant, with reference to repairs to the schools in the St. Regis Agency. I wrote you in connection with this matter on June 23, and, on reviewing our file, I find that a typographical mistake was made in my letter of May 11. This should have read $600.00 instead of $500.00.

Under separate cover you are being forwarded an accountable advance of $200.00 for labour for repairs. I note your statement regarding the purchase of materials, and, as you know, purchases from any one firm must not exceed $50.00.

The Department agrees with your suggestion, to finish the sun-room of the teacher's residence with V-lap, with a view to ascertaining if this makes a satisfactory job. When this is completed you will know its cost and you will then be able to more accurately estimate what expenditure will be required to complete other rooms in the building where the condition of the plaster is unsatisfactory.

Philip Phelan,

Re: Saint Régis Indian Day School, (Huntington, Que.)

Dear Mr. Phelan:

The Reverend Sisters of Saint Anne, in charge of the above school complain that there is no room provided for culinary classes and other such social work in the above school.

As it is at the present time these classes have to be given in the sisters convent at considerable annoyances as the quarters are extremely small. Moreover, the water service is very rudimentary.

What the Reverend Sisters desire, is an enlargement of the school with provisions for a social work classroom and the installation of an adequate water service.

This improvement could very well be done during the summer months and made ready for the September opening.

Hoping that you will attend to this matter as soon as possible I remain, dear Mr. Phelan,

yours very truly,

J. O. Flourde, O.M.I.
July 13, 1948.

St. Regis Village Indian Day School.

Dear Father Plourde:

I have for answer your letter of July 6, addressed to Mr. Phelan, concerning the St. Regis Village Indian School.

I have recently had an opportunity of inspecting this school and the work done there by the Reverend Sisters of St. Ann. In view of more urgent requirements on reserves where we have no educational facilities or on which our buildings are extremely dilapidated, it will be some two or three years before we can consider the erection of a new school at St. Regis.

We have just finished a new two-room school on this reserve to replace two very old buildings. The erection of a new school at St. Regis is one which we project in the years to come rather than during this summer.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard P. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Mr. Wescott:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 19th with attached Inspector's reports on the Caughnawaga Schools and the St. Regis Schools.

The various matters of these reports will be the subject of further correspondence but I note that you have found the work of Miss Terrance to be unsatisfactory.

I was able to visit the St. Regis Schools in the middle of June and I concur entirely in your comments concerning the Chetlain School. Of course, this school will be closed down next year and the children will be attending the new two room school at Chenail. It is not our intention to employ Miss Terrance at this new school at Chenail and we have appointed a Miss Comeau from New Brunswick as the Senior teacher. Miss Francis will handle the Junior Room.

I was very frank in discussing conditions in her classroom with Miss Terrance and told her that we would not consider her for the new school at Chenail. I have made the suggestion that she transfer to the Caughnawaga School where she can be kept under constant supervision. I have not as yet heard as to whether this transfer will be acceptable to all concerned.
I also note your recommendation with regard to our requirements at St. Regis. I doubt if we can include this in our 1949-50 building program but hope to include in our 1950-51 project this item.

In conclusion may I again express the appreciation of our Department to you for the sincere interest which you take in our schools and for the valuable assistance which you render annually to our teachers.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Mr. A.E. Wescott,
Inspector of Schools,

Extract from Inspector (school) A.L. Wescott's report on his visit to the schools of the St. Regis Agency. Report dated July 19th; original on file 1-1-6, Quebec.

"It may be presumed that you are already considering the building of a new school house to replace the present village school. The present building is not adequate for the excellent school program, including the manual arts, which you are trying to implement in your schools.

"I respectfully suggest that, when you plan a new building for St. Regis Village, you study the possibility of transporting the children of St. Regis Island to and from the future village school. The children of the Island could be transported by boat in the autumn and in the spring, by sleigh in winter. There would be only a few days at the beginning and at the end of winter when one or the other of these means of transportation could not be used.

"This suggestion, of course, is based on my own opinion. The feasibility of such a project would have to be studied by the local superintendent and others who know the situation at first hand.

"The cost of transporting the pupils would be offset by many advantages, both educational and financial. The pupils would have all the benefits of the educational activities that you are endeavouring to provide for the Indian children. It would no longer be necessary to provide a teacher and a teacher's living quarters and a school house for an average enrolment of twelve pupils. It may be noted that the present school house on the Island is in need of repair or replacement."

Re: Voucher No. 106 - $66.75,
Graham McGerrigle, Huntingdon, P.Q.

The above voucher, which is recommended for payment, represents labour and materials supplied in connection with the changeover of our pumping system at the Teachers' residence, St. Regis Village, from gas to electric operation.

As we are not blessed with mechanics in our janitor service who can properly look after a gas operated engine, we have experienced considerable trouble in the past with this unit at the Sisters' residence with the result that quite often no water supply was available. While we are using the same pump, it being now equipped to operate electrically, the Sisters can look after this themselves in accordance with their requirements.

J. L. Bernah,
Superintendent,
St. Regis Agency.

Encl.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

On the 1st instant I phoned Mr. Phelan regarding the purchase of a stove to heat the Junior Room of the St. Regis Village School. Heating this particular room has presented quite a problem as there is a 14-ft. ceiling and it is a very large room. It had originally been planned, I understand, to heat the two rooms by means of a furnace but on account of the low location it was found that, after digging the cellar for the school, it was full of water with the result that the plan of installing a furnace was abandoned. I checked the temperature in the Junior Room and for several consecutive days it was impossible to get anything above 60 degrees.

I had planned to get one of those Warm Morning heaters to install in this room at a cost of $69.50. There is a draft regulator on them similar to some of the more modern brooder stoves. However, at the same time, the heater at the St. Regis Island School gave out and I put the Warm Morning heater over at St. Regis Island. We put in a large No. 2205 Perfection oil heater in the R.C.M.P. Office a year ago at a cost of $93.33. It has a heating capacity for 9,000 cubic feet. The officer in charge of the detachment here found it too large a capacity heater so I installed this particular unit in the Junior Room of the Village School and placed a smaller oil stove in the R.C.M.P. Office. We are now getting good satisfaction in the Junior Room at the school.
As the writer would like to see this particular unit left at the school, I am wondering if it would be possible for an arrangement to be worked out so that, if necessary, the purchase price in the amount of $93.33 could be transferred from Schools to Agency vote. Insofar as fuel oil is concerned, I have arranged with Mr. White, who supplies our Chenail School residence with fuel, to supply us.

I would like to suggest that we install another oil burning unit in the Senior Room at the Village School some time during the coming summer so that we can put it into operation for next fall and, upon hearing from you concerning this matter, information will be supplied in order that a heater of proper capacity can be obtained. Insofar as any coal that we might have left over at the St. Regis Village School, this will not represent any loss as it will simply be transferred next winter to the St. Regis Island School.

T. L. Donahue,
Superintendent,
St. Regis Agency.
24th February, 1949.

Mr. T.L. Bonnah,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
P.O. Box 987,
Cornwall, Ontario.

With regards to the last paragraph of your letter you can forward a requisition after 1st April, 1949, for the type of heater which you consider will give satisfaction in the Senior Room of the St. Regis Village Day School.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,-

For many years past the teachers of the St. Regis Village, Chenail and St. Regis Island Schools have been boarding with Mrs. Smith in the village. She has notified them that she will not take boarders any longer.

There is no other place in the village where they can board, but they told me that there is a house owned by Mrs. Gorrell which could be had. They all get along well together, and if they had a house they could board themselves. The house is partly furnished and they would be quite willing to try living there.

I would suggest that we write to Mr. Agent Taillon and make inquiries about this house of Mrs. Gorrell's.
Ottawa, June 30, 1919.

Dear Taillon,

The St. Regis teachers who have been living with Mrs. Smith inform me that she will not be able to keep them after the summer holidays.

I am told that there is a house belonging to a Mrs. Gorrell, which would suit, if it could be had on reasonable terms. I would like you to find out what the Gorrells would rent the house for. I believe it is partially furnished and I should like to know exactly what furniture they would leave in it and what would be required. I understand they would need four single beds and these can be got at a reasonable rate from the Militia Department. You might send me a list of the furniture that you think would be required, with the probable cost of each article. I should like to have this information as soon as possible, as the Department is disposed to provide accommodation for these teachers, if a suitable house can be secured.

Yours sincerely,

F. E. Taillon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Ottawa, July 28, 1920.

Sir,

The lease from James Hemlock of St. Regis of the house used as a teacher's residence on the St. Regis Reserve expired on the 30th of June, last.

I have to request that you will be good enough to state your opinion as to whether you consider steps should be taken to further provide a residence for the teachers of the St. Regis Reserve and, if so, if it would not be possible to secure a house suitable for the purpose at a moderate rent. Some of the teachers have requested that they be allowed to board in Hogansburg, having made arrangements to be taken to and from their schools by car. The Department underwent considerable expense in furnishing the house last year and I have to request that you will be good enough to state what disposition was made of the articles supplied in fitting up the house and you should give an inventory of the same. As we have these on hand it might be well, if possible to do so, to rent another house and the equipment on hand should be sufficient to furnish it.

Kindly give this matter your prompt attention and inform the Department as to what you consider the best to be done regarding the matter; also, if a house cannot be secured, would it be possible for the teachers to obtain boarding accommodation.

Your obedient servant,

OTTAWA, July 13th, 1921.

Sir,

I beg to refer you to official letter of September 14th, 1920, regarding lease of house from Peter Garrow to be used as a teacher's residence on the St. Regis Reserve. As it will, no doubt, be necessary to continue this arrangement for the next school year, I have to request that you will obtain a lease of this house at the same rental. You should draw up a lease and have it signed by Peter Garrow and forward a copy to the Department.

The lease should contain a clause giving the Department the right to renew for a further period.

You will be good enough to give this matter your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

F. E. Taillon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, P.Q.
Dear Mr. Taillon,

Your letter was received this morning asking about the house. We will be down at St. Regis again before very long and I will have a talk over my self about the place of course. Cannot say just when but before Sept. anyway I was in to see you before last but you were not there so they were lot of dishes broken and Mrs. Condon't find all the linen again which she left there for the tea. We got the sheep last Monday from the department and we thank you very much for it.

Yours truly,

Pete L. Garrod

July 32, 1921
Sir,

In reference to yours of July 7th instant #33-4-5, and in particular to that portion of your letter relative to the renewal of lease of teachers' residence for another year, I beg herewith to enclose a letter which I have just received from Mr Garrow concerning the house.

From the tone of the letter, and a previous conversation, I am under the impression that unless the Department is prepared to pay for whatever material has been destroyed, I fear we will not be able to secure a house for the teachers; for the only available and suitable one is this particular house.

Personally I am aware that both Miss McGrath and Miss McParland were very hard on the household material as they seemingly did not take very good care of things and it may have been while they were here that the things named in the attached letter disappeared.

I think that unless you are prepared to allow them for the loss sustained, they will not rent the house for another year.

Kindly let me have your decision, so that I may be in a position to tell them what you will do in the matter.

J.D. McLean, Sec.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

OTTAWA, August 10th, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo relative to the renewal of lease of the teacher's residence in the village of St. Regis, for another year, and stating that the present owner refuses to renew this lease unless he is compensated for damages to the furnishings which he claims were destroyed by former teachers.

In reply, I beg to say that in December, last, you forwarded an account to the amount of $21.00 in favour of James Henlock for damages sustained to a rocker and a Quebec heater, which was not allowed. It is considered that Peter Garrow in refusing to renew the lease unless he is also paid damages is a "hold-up" on his part. However, in order that a residence can be obtained for the teachers, and as his seems to be the only one available, the Department will be prepared to allow him a reasonable amount for any damage that was done, and I will be pleased if you will forward immediately a properly certified account covering the amount due. You can inform Mr. Garrow that the Department will pay a reasonable amount, and you should endeavour to obtain a renewal of the lease for the same rent as last year and forward a copy to the Department. If he refuses to sign the lease until he receives a cheque for compensation, you will be good enough to forward the account as asked for at once.

Kindly give this matter your prompt attention.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Aest. Deputy & Secretary.

F. E. Taillon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, P.Q.

It is further agreed that the party of the first part will have the house banked for the winter and also supply double windows as well as all the necessary cooking utensils, dishes, and bed clothing.

Sir,

Referring to yours of the 10th instant #33-6-8 regarding the renewal of lease for the teachers residence, I beg to herewith inclose lease from Peter Garrow for the school year 1921-1922. I endeavored to secure the lease for a longer term but he stated that there was a possibility of his requiring the house at that time and therefore, he would not consent to a longer period.

As to the claim for damages, he has agreed to accept $10.00 for articles broken and missing, which I consider reasonable and would recommend for payment.

Your refer to my letter of December last to a claim for $21.00 in favour of James Hemlock and which you did not entertain, allow me to say with all respect that I believe Hemlock is legally, morally and equitably entitled to the amount claimed, although you have ruled otherwise.

Owing to the fact that it is difficult to secure suitable boarding places or houses for the accommodation of the teachers, may I offer the following suggestions, that during the summer of 1922 a modern residence should be erected upon the school lot for the teachers, thereby doing away with the necessity of renting houses which at best are not altogether suitable for the purpose.

While writing of teachers recall to mind that I made application for the placing of Sisters in charge of the village school and your reply was that no suitable residence was available; if you will follow my suggestion and erect a house, we could secure the nuns for the reopening of the school for the September 1922 term.

As you are well aware wherever the Sisters are in charge of the Indian schools much more satisfactory work is done. Mr Inspector Gilman, Inspector for the Protestant Provincial Board of Education and who inspects these schools for the Department has only words of praise for the wonderful work being done at the Caughnawaga school where they are serving; he always urges me to do my utmost to secure for the village at least the Sisters.

I hope you may give the matter your valuable consideration and that when the school year 1922-1923 arrives we will have installed 'Les bonnes soeurs.'

J.D. McLean, Sec.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa, August 23, 1921

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, enclosing a lease from Peter Garrow of his house to be used as a teachers' residence on the St. Regis Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that this is satisfactory. It is noted that the rent, namely, $15.00 per month, is payable on the first day of each month during the term of this lease, and you will be good enough to forward each month a certified voucher, in duplicate, for the amount of rent due.

With reference to Peter Garrow's claim for damages, you may forward a certified voucher, in duplicate, for $10.00. You may also forward another certified voucher, in duplicate, for $21.00, covering the claim of James Hemlock.

With reference to these claims for damages done to the contents of the teachers' residence, I would point out that no such claims will be considered in future, unless received before payment of teachers' salaries has been made as it is felt that the teachers are liable for any damage done to the furniture.

The Department notes your suggestion that a modern residence be erected during the summer of 1922 and that sisters be engaged to take charge of the schools in St. Regis Village.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, stating that you will be unable to renew the lease of the house owned by you in St. Regis Village and which has been used as a residence for the teachers of the Village and Island Indian day schools.

In reply I beg to say it is regretted there has been delay in the payment of the rental of this building, which has been occasioned by neglect on the part of the Indian Agent in forwarding vouchers for same. I may say it is expected that a cheque covering the rental due for the months of April, May and June, last, to the amount of $45, will be sent you in the course of a day or so. The Department is very anxious to obtain a renewal of the lease of this house for another year, and we hope that, in view of the above explanation, you will reconsider your decision and agree to allow the teachers to occupy this building until June 30, 1927. We will pay the rental during the next year, monthly, if you so desire, upon receipt of a letter from you at the end of each month requesting the amount due. September 23rd, 1926.

Memorandum.

Mrs. Garrow, the owner of the house occupied by the teachers of the St. Regis Village School, visited the Department yesterday and matters effecting the residence were discussed and settled as follows:

1. She complained that a number of the chairs had been broken by the teachers. My opinion is that some of the chairs got out of repair through use. It was impossible, however, to convince Mrs. Garrow of this and it was decided to have it understood that three kitchen chairs purchased recently by the Department would be considered Mrs. Garrow's property to replace the chairs she claims were broken.

2. It was also decided that two of the toilet sets in the bedrooms should be considered Mrs. Garrow's property.

3. It was agreed that the following articles of furniture belong to the Department:

   (a) 1 Dresser.
   1 Stand - These are in the small bedroom upstairs.

   (b) 3 Beds.

It should be noted that these articles should be added to the list of supplies purchased this year for the residence by the Department.

4. It was agreed that all the bed clothes at present in the residence are the property of the Department.

5. Blinds were purchased this year for the windows as the other blinds had worn out. As the windows are an odd size and the blinds had to be cut specially for them, it might be as well to leave them in the residence when the Department vacates same.

In reply I beg to say that, as you are being advised by telegram of today's date, the transfer of Miss Prudhomme has been cancelled. It is considered that there should be an ample supply of bedding on hand for the new teacher who will be appointed to the St. Regis Island Indian Day School.

February 1, 1927.

MEMORANDUM FOR:

I examined the teachers' residence at St. Regis Village on Saturday last, when on the reserve, and I am satisfied that it is not worth purchasing with a view to remodelling and addition. I believe that a new residence is urgent, so that we will be able to keep the rather good personal services which we now have at this point. The Village residence should provide accommodation for three teachers and additional accommodation for the Chetlain and Chansil teachers, who make it their home over the weekends. A suitable location would have to be secured. I have made a note for 1927-28 Estimates.

At the time of my visit, I laid down rules in connection with the residence and definitely placed Miss MacNulty, the Village senior teacher, in charge.

I propose to write to the Indian Agent, authorizing the purchase of one mattress, which is required.

Memorandum:

MR. ORR,

There is an item in the Supplementary Estimates, of $5,000, for the purpose of erecting a teachers' residence at St. Regis Village. It is very important that this building be completed this year, as we are apt to lose the splendid teaching services we have engaged, unless a suitable home is provided. I am asking Mr. Indian Agent MacGibbon to look into the question of a suitable lot (see file 33-6-9). I would like to suggest that this building be advertised along with the Cornwall Island classroom (33-4-5) as it is possible a better price could be secured if the contract was awarded as a whole. Both sites can be easily reached by water from Cornwall.

Accommodation in the St. Regis Village teachers' residence is required for 4 teachers. I would suggest that two bedrooms be larger than the others - one for the principal and the other for the week-end accommodation of a second teacher - the girl from Chetlain, who lives in the village from Friday until Sunday. A fair sized living room and dining room should be provided.

The basement should be large enough for not only the furnace but for storing food, etc.

Gentlemen:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo and I note, with regret, that you are being put to inconvenience and extra expense in connection with your contract for the erection of a teachers' residence at St. Regis.

Arrangements were again made for the presence of the police on the reserve on the first instant, and I am very hopeful that there will be no further interference.

Sir,

I beg to enclose list of supplies for the Teacher's New Residence, St. Regis Village. This list was handed to me by Miss Macaulay, Teacher. There are a lot of supplies on the list which are not really necessary at present; of course there are some that are, such as stove, table, chairs, etc., that are absolutely necessary to have before the teachers move in. These should be purchased as soon as possible, in order to be moved in the new house by December the first. Mr. Lalonde, head carpenter, left this afternoon, November 15th. He handed me the keys of the house, also instructed me the running of the furnace; which he said should be kept going, as the plaster is not thoroughly dry yet. The house is completed with the exception of the flush electric switches, and they are being put on the last of this week, as the floors are newly varnished, and will not be thoroughly dry until then.

There is a little matter on which I want information on, is, that Miss Stacey, teacher of St. Regis Island School, asked me if she could be entitled to have a room in the New Residence, St. Regis Village, on week ends, if she desired. Miss Stacey visits friends at Hemmingburg occasionally, and it happens sometimes she would stay over in St. Regis; therefore this room would be a good clean place to stay. Miss Stacey does not care to stay over night in most of the places in St. Regis Village. There are four bed-rooms in the new house, so there is plenty of room. Of course Miss Stacey could have to be warned to take none of her friends in the new house. I think there is just a little bit of off feeling between the other teachers and Miss Stacey.

November 25th, 1927.

Memorandum:-

Re:- St. Regis Village Teachers' Residence.

Miss MacNulty advised me on the 24th instant that both the inside windows and the storm windows of the new teachers' residence require cleaning. Several of them are streaked with paint. I promised her that the Agent would be instructed to arrange for the cleaning.
Sir,

I beg to say that the teachers moved in the new teachers residence, St. Regis Village, today, November 29/27. The Village School and Chenail School were closed for the day, the teachers assisting in moving. I hired Mr. Lawrence Hoppa with his team and wagon for transferring house-hold goods to new house, and was assisted by Mr. Mitchell Thomas. Tomorrow I will have the window shades on and dry closet placed.

I may say regarding the cistern in basement of new house. When the contractors constructed and completed the cement cistern they notified me that it was O.K. for water. I had the cistern good three-quarters full of water when I noticed it leaking, leaking fast and getting worse. I went over to Cornwall the following morning, notified the contractors they came over, dried the cistern and gave it a coat of good strong cement both inside and out, which I am satisfied is a good lasting job. At present there is barely one foot of water in cistern. If this cistern was full I don't think the teachers would go short of soft water during the winter months.

I Am,
Your Obedient Servant.

Sir:

I beg to say regarding the trip to Cornwall, Ont., by Miss Mac Lulity, teacher of St. Regis Village school, and Mr. Phelan of the Indian Department Ottawa, on November 24th/27, to purchase supplies, furniture, etc., for the teachers new residence, St. Regis Village. I was instructed to hire an Indian with a motor boat to proceed to Cornwall on the same day, to bring back the supplies purchased. I hired Mr. George Jacobs, of St. Regis, who runs a motor boat, the day was very windy and rough on the water, and I had some difficulty in securing someone to venture the trip, but Mr. Jacobs consented to go, and got within a mile from Cornwall and had to turn back, on account of rough water. It happened that Tom Thomas was over to Cornwall that day, with motor boat and snow, and he brought over the supplies next morning. I consider that Mr. Jacobs is entitled to pay for his trip, which is $2.00. He done the best he could considering the weather. I might say that I would have sent this in sooner, but on account of Mr. Jacobs being away for a short time prevented me doing so.

I Am,

Memorandum.

Mr. Orr,

During my recent visit to St. Regis I took occasion to look over the teachers' residence recently constructed in St. Regis Village.

The teachers called my attention to the unsatisfactory performance of the heating system. It appears that some of the registers have no heat in them whatever and that as a result some of the rooms are too cold to sit in. They also stated that the sun room windows were so drafty that they could not use that room on a windy day and that the back door was so badly sprung that they have had to close it permanently during the winter.

Would it not be possible to bring these matters to the attention of the contractor?

Inspector.

St Regis, Que., May 4th, 1928.

Sir:

Teacher's residence, St Regis Village.

The Teachers who reside in this building have been annoyed considerably this last while back, with cattle in this yard around the house. The teachers request that a fence be placed around this yard, for protection against cattle and other animals.

The approximate material and cost for construction of this fence would be:

- 7 rods page wire, 4 ft. high, 73 cents per yd. $5.11
- 14 posts at 25 cents per $3.50
- Fence braces, 5 @ $5.00
- Steeples @ $50
- 10 foot gate @ $12.00
- Labour @ $15.00

Total $41.11

The above is for 18 strand, steel page wire. If a lawn fence was constructed, the costs would be a great deal higher.

Please advise me as to the intentions of the Department regarding the above matter.

Your obedient servant,

W. A. McGibbon.
Agent.
Ottawa, May 8th, 1925.

Sir:

With reference to that portion of your letter of the 4th instant, relative to the request of the teachers that the yard around the residence in St. Regis Village be fenced, and giving an approximate cost of the material and labour, I beg to say that the Department will approve of your arranging to have this work carried out. You should arrange for the purchase of the quantity of Page wire, posts, braces, steeples and for the 10' gate required, and also for the labour in having the fence erected. We note that you estimate the total cost of the material and labour to be approximately $41.

When this work has been completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the fencing material and also for the labour in erecting the fence. You should see that the work in erecting this fence is satisfactorily carried out.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

M. A. MacGibbon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

There still remains the question of poles. No ordinary pole fits these windows, as you will see from dimensions on separate sheet. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter of July 3rd, '28, informing me that there is a leak around the chimney in the teachers residence, St. Regis Village.

I notified Atchison & Co. of Cornwall, Ont., about two weeks ago, about this leak. They said they would repair the leak as soon as possible. I again notified them on July 4th, '28. They promised to attend to the matter at once. I expect the trouble is in the flashing of the chimney, and which can be easily remedied.

Regarding the overflow pipe in the cistern, I beg to say that there is an overflow pipe in this cistern, but on account of the drainage pipe running only to the outside of the well in the basement of this building, the overflow pipe is of little use; however, I will take care of this possible overflow by disconnecting the water conductors, on the outside of this building, which I have already done.

I will visit this residence now and again, and notify the Department if anything goes wrong.

I Am,

Your Obedient Servant,

W.A. MacGibbon
Agent.

Madam:

I have to inform you that Miss M. Stacey, teacher of the St. Regis Island Indian Day School, has requested permission to use the spare room in the teacher's residence in the village whenever she has to stop over night and on Sundays. Please let the Department have a recommendation without delay. I understand that Miss Legarde of the Chetlain School does not use this room at all.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,

Miss M. MacNulty,
St. Regis,
P. Q.
St. Regis, Que.

Dear Sir,

In reply to letter No. 33-6-8 of Oct. 31st, I might say that Miss Stacey came to me a month or more ago, asking permission to week-end here, and I replied as follows:

"The spare room is not furnished."

It might be advisable then for you to write her personally and corroborate my statement; which is just how matters are.

After consulting the girls, I feel that the granting of this privilege to an Indian would be a step in the wrong direction, and one you would regret taking, as the preservation of the prevailing harmony among the girls should be given first consideration.

The Hotel is open for guests, and I feel sure that there are other Indian people who will keep her if she
will only pay for her trouble. Miss Legarde has never asked to stay, simply because she week-
ends in Hogansburg with her friend's family.

Trusting this will prove satisfactory,

Sincerely,

Margaret MacNully.

Mrs. R.V. Ferrier,
Ottawa,
Ont.

Sir:

I have to authorize you to provide a check valve at the bottom of the kitchen pump at the St. Regis Village teachers' residence. You should also have two steps built at the base of the soft water cistern. Further, you should place above that portion of the smoke pipe which is near the furnace some insulating or protecting material. Asbestos might be advisable for this purpose. You may purchase a fire basket for the fireplace in the living room. You may authorize Miss MacNulty to secure some edging for the upstairs linoleum runner and to lightly tack it to the floor. You should also examine the legs of the four beds and determine what type of steel or glass glides would be suitable. These are necessary to protect the floor.

The Department wishes you to look after these improvements at your convenience and to arrange for the accounts to be presented in about a month's time, when the new Vote will be available.

St. Regis, Que.
November 19th, 1932.

Sir,

I beg to say that the grates in the kitchen Quebec Heater Cook Stove, at teacher's residence, St. Regis Village, are broken, burnt out, and need to be replaced. Also a grate shaker is needed.

In October last, the teachers informed me that the water in the cistern in the basement of the residence, due to being in the cistern all summer, had a very bad smell, and was unfit for use. I had the cistern cleaned out by Jake Day, Bonaparte, and other Indians, who were on relief. They used the cistern pump to dry the cistern. On putting the pump back to its right place, one of the side lugs got accidentally broke, which makes the pump useless. A new pump will have to be purchased, which will cost around $3.00.

The above are necessary, and would like to be authorized to purchase them, pump, grates and shaker.

Your obedient servant,

St. Regis Quebec,
February 18th 1936.

Sir,

I have to inform you that the water pipes of the St. Regis Village Teacher's residence froze during the severe cold weather of January making it necessary to employ Mr. Parker a plumber of Cornwall to do the repairing. They again burst a few days later, in the flooring beneath the bath room, same place as they froze before. I therefore consulted Mr. Parker as to the best method of protecting the pipes. The pipes were repaired and packed around to protect them from the frost and we also placed valves in the pipes leading to the second floor, with draining taps so they could be closed and drained during severe cold weather, and also the water could be shut off if they froze again.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa.

October 5th, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I have to advise that the eaves-troughing on the St. Regis Village Teacher's residence should be replaced in parts. They are leaking and in some places have become broken. They are not in a condition to carry sufficient water to fill the cistern during a rainy spell, with the result that the Teachers' have had to have their soft water carted from the river.

At the present time only 2/3 of the roof sheds water into troughing delivered to the cistern. The balance was caught in a barrel or wasted. It is proposed to have all spouting deliver water to the cistern.

Mr. Parker of Cornwall informs me the most practical method would be to charge for the manufactured troughing, 25¢ per foot, plus labor, etc., cost of installing.

It will all depend upon the condition of the pipes as to what the total cost would be. Some of the old troughing may be used. The total cost would be around $30.00. If I may have permission I can have this work done in time to catch the fall rains. Please advise and oblige.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.
EX'D.

St. Regis Quebec,
July 19, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I wish to advise of certain repairs required at the St. Regis Village teacher's residence.

A complete set (4 bars) of grates for the furnace. Six Gav. smoke pipes, two elbows with check draft inset. The plaster ceiling of the kitchen has become cracked, threatens to fall, requires repairing. The most practical method is to use Plaster board or gyproc. A portion of the plastered wall under the window sill of the sun room requires repairing, and cause of seepage of rain water remedied. Through settling of the building the cellar door and the bath room door (directly overhead) will have to be rehung, so as to close properly.

The walls and ceilings throughout should be morescoed or painted. The kitchen, sitting room hallways, three bedrooms, particularly require renovating. There are several large cracks in the wall of one of the bedrooms, near chimney which require to be filled. We have trouble with the drain leading from the cellar. It may be that the septic tank has become decayed and will not function properly. The drain may have to be reopened the box examined and possibly replaced. Costs in connection with this will be problematical in accord with repairs required.

Walls and ceilings of rooms to be painted will have to be washed as they are quite sticky and greasy. It is proposed to employ Indian labour. I attach a list of parts and material required, with approximate costs.

Material etc

Dear Sir:

Repairs, Teachers' Residence

With reference to the enclosed voucher No. 15-85 for $40.00 in favour of James Hemlock for labour in connection with renovations at the St. Regis Village Teachers' residence.

The entire ceiling of the Kitchen was recailed with Gyproc as well as repairs to wall beneath window of Sun room. All rooms with exception of one bedroom received a thorough washing. Kitchen and bathroom received two coats of paint. Dining room, Parlor, Sun room, three bedrooms, two hallways and Vestibule received two coats of Muresco. New blinds in sun room.

New Grates and smoke pipes was installed on the Furnace. Drain to Cess pool was cleared with use of a drain chain and thoroughly flushed. Drain now servicable, may have to be opened later.

Some additional costs for labour, as it was found two coats of Muresco was require to make an unstreaky finish, whereas one coat was figured on, in submitting costs.

Interior now has a greatly improved appearance.

St. Regis Quebec,
July 21, 1943.

Phillip Phelan, Esq.,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 12th, 1943, regarding living accommodation for Miss Terrance teacher at the Chenail Indian Day school.

You ask why Miss Terrance is not living in the residence at the Village. They are mitigating reasons.

When Miss Terrance taught at the village school during the temporary absence of Miss McDonald she chose to reside at her home just south of Hogensburgh, a 2½ mile drive and had her meals at the residence. Then she changed to having her meals at an Indian home, with Mrs Joe Sawatis.

When Miss Terrance was appointed Teacher at the Chenail school, she chose to reside at home and drive to her work. By doing so she reached by car over roads kept open the year round, and passable, excepting for a period following severe snow storms; the school more conveniently than she could if living at the Village teachers' residence, from where it means a walk of a mile and one half, being ferried across St. Regis River during the summer months. This worked good until last winters severe weather and heavy storms with consequent blocking of all roads. She could not conveniently reach her school at such times and decided that she had best stay at the residence. She was advised there was room for her there and the teachers resident at the residence were also advised, but, Miss McDonald, especially, strenuously objected to have an Indian girl reside with them, and gave Miss Terrance the cold shoulder. In consequence Miss Terrance did not move to the residence but at such times as there was heavy travelling stayed with Miss Sawatis in the village, and at other times made her way home.

In addition Miss Terrance has said that she wished to reside at home with her mother who has not fully recovered from a car accident, which occurred last fall. If she stayed on the staff she has intimated that she would drive to her work, and has voiced a preference to an appointment at the village school, where she could reach in a few minutes by car.

Miss Terrance was
Miss Terrance was quite aware that as far as the Department was concerned she was quite welcome to avail herself of the accommodation provided at the residence. But there was that uncongenial atmosphere.

I must advise that Miss Caza did not voice, to me, any objection to having Miss Terrance live at the residence.

In passing I may advise that Miss McDonald has been her and taken away her effects while she advised me that she did not resign from the service of the Branch, we are losing her services here. That means there will be an opening for Miss Terrance if it is found advisable to give her one of the appointments at the village school. I have suggested that she accept the position at the St. Regis Island school. She would not take it under consideration, saying that she wished to be placed so she could go to her duties from her home. Miss Terrance is inclined to be quite fleshy, a heavy weight, and does not like foot travel, especially over heavy roads.

It is now quite possible, that due to the departure of Miss McDonald, that an Indian lady teacher will be find a changed attitude by other teachers residing at the residence. At least I hope so.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
St. Regis, Que.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Reverend Mother General has informed me that you wish me to submit a list of the articles which I believe necessary for the teachers' residence in Saint Regis. I am enclosing this list with this letter.

I wish to draw your special attention to the fact that we have asked for coil mattresses. We have specified Beauty Rest but of course another make of coil mattress will do as well. The four washstands which are in the residence at the present time, will also serve our purpose.

You will probably be surprised to notice that we have requested bedroom equipment for six. This is explained by the fact that four sisters will reside in St. Regis: the two teachers, the housekeeper and a fourth one who will stay with the housekeeper during the day. Of course, we expect to have visitors occasionally so we have asked for two additional beds.

The kitchen equipment is also scanty; this explains the rather large list we are sending to you.

All papers duly filled will be forwarded to you within a day or two.

Thanking you for your kind attention to all these matters, I beg to remain

Yours very respectfully,

Sister Mary Zita, S.S.A.
