Mr. Philip Phalen,
Ottawa.

My dear Sir,

No doubt, it will interest you to hear about St. Regis Mission.

We arrived on Aug. 26 and found a pretty little home awaiting us. But I am sorry to say that it has no commodities for sisters.

Would you kindly allow us to hire a carpenter who could put shelves in a wall cupboard, upstairs, for blankets etc. Also to board off a small space between the stairs and kitchen to form a cupboard for our school apparel and to store away brooms.

For the sake of privacy, we need doors.
on the parlor and the Community room. Besides these are a few other little repairs to be made throughout the house.

We registered about forty-five pupils on Sept. 1 but started school only on Sept. 7 with sixty pupils on the Roll Call. Bad weather prevented the painters from finishing for Sept. 1.

Mr. McNaughton told me about two weeks ago that the beds had been ordered but they have not yet come. We did not get the typewriters either.

I am happy to say that he and Mr. Bonnah are doing their best to make life pleasant for us at St. Regis.

We were sorry to find the school books in such a condition—torn and scribbled upon. Therefore we take the liberty of sending in a requisition for the books needed. You can rely upon us to see that the children take good care of them.

Trusting that you will not find us too exacting.

I remain,

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]

Sister Mary Rita, S.S.T. Principal

Mr. R.A.Hoey, Esq. Supt. Welfare & Training.

When Inspector Thibault was here some time ago we discussed the question of getting water for the teachers' residence in the village. Since his visit I have been making inquiries to ascertain if a solution could be found for our problem but so far have met with little success.

There is a cistern in the cellar at the residence with a hook-up to a hand operated pressure tank which supplies water for the taps and bathroom. However unless we have plenty of rain there is no way of filling the cistern except by hauling water. When the cistern goes dry, which is quite often, this means no water is available for the hot water tank as well which is hooked up to the furnace with the result that the furnace coil, from not having water in it, has been useless and often requires replacement. Since it has been necessary to keep the furnace on steadily for the past couple of months the water system could not be used and consequently water has to be carried upstairs, where it is held in the bath tub, for operation of the toilet unit.

There is little use in putting in a new furnace coil unless water can be kept in the cistern and this means continuous expense for this purpose as it takes about 20 barrels to make an impression in the cistern and this costs twenty-five cents per bbl. and 20 bbls. lasts about ten days or thereabouts. Since the furnace has been on steadily no water has been put in the cistern and there is little use unless the coil in the furnace is replaced but when that is done, water...
will have to be kept up in the cistern. There is no drinking water on the premises and this has to be carried from a neighbouring Indian home or from the school yard pump.

The only permanent solution I can see would be to install a small Briggs-Stratton gas engine which would operate a pump of sufficient capacity to draw the water from the school well and store it in a pressure tank in the basement of the residence. This would then give the teachers water for all purposes. The other alternative is to drill an artesian well on the grounds and pipe it into the house to the pressure tank. However files available on drilling artesian wells at this agency would indicate this to be a very expensive proposition.

During the remainder of this winter it would seem advisable to have the hot water coil repaired in the furnace and the cistern kept full of water in the cellar and I would recommend that authority be granted to undergo the necessary expenditure until a permanent solution is found.

[Signature]

Clerk in charge.
Ottawa, January 10, 1944.

Mr. C. D. Roberts, In charge Indian Agency
St. Regis, Que.

Philip Phelan, Esq. Chief, Training Division.

With further reference to my letter of Dec. 28th., last anent the water situation at the Village Teachers' Residence, I might advise as follows.

I had an opportunity of discussing this question with a qualified plumber last week and after looking the situation over from all angles it was decided it was not possible to arrange a hook-up with the well across the road in the School lot and have it pumped into a pressure tank at the residence. You will recall I discussed this with you while in Ottawa.

Unfortunately there is only a 6" casing in the artesian well at school and with the piping and foot valve down in the casing it is not possible to place more plumbing in such a small space. A foot valve would also have to be put into the intended system as well. After considering this, digging costs and levels to be contended with, it would not appear advisable to consider my first suggestion. The only alternative is to have a well drilled or dug right on the house lot and a small gas engine to pump the water into a larger pressure tank in the residence basement. Digging may not be practicable as there appears to be a slate strata underneath the subsoil. The extent of this of course, I cannot say.

The above for your information and necessary action.

T.L. Bonnah
Clerk in charge.

Dear Sir:

The present school-year is quickly coming to an end and I have every reason to believe that our Sisters have devoted their best efforts in behalf of the interests of the native children of Saint Regis Mission. In fact, they have labored strenuously in a supreme endeavor to raise the educational level of their charges.

I wish to thank you and the Department of Indian Affairs for the assistance you gave the teachers in their work as well as for every step taken by you to give them some measure of comfort in the residence.

At this time when the General Administration is checking up on the most pressing needs of our various establishments, I would like to draw your attention to the unsatisfactory heating system in the teachers' residence. Reports show that the furnace is much too small to assure necessary warmth, and as none of the windows or doors are weather-proof, the sisters suffered very much from the intensive cold during the winter months.

Another cause of considerable inconvenience is the insufficiency of domestic water. Proper sanitation and hygiene are impossible under existing conditions. Mr. Doucet, who inspected the house, will know that our complaint is justified.

Though it may seem early to be planning for the next year, I feel that I should not delay to expose a situation to which I would ask you to give your personal and immediate attention in order to relieve the sisters of these water and heat worries. I hardly believe it would be possible for the sisters to resume another winter under similar difficulties.

Thanking you most sincerely, I remain

Very truly yours,

[Signature]
Superior General.

I can assure you that we will do everything possible to make them comfortable.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

R.A. Hoey, Esq. Supt. Welfare & Training.

With reference to yours of June 5th, please be advised that the water system has now been installed in the village teachers' residence from the school artesian well. Vouchers are going forward under separate cover for this item.

You will notethat it was not possible to keep within the limited amount specified in your letter. However, I have done as well as can be in regards to keeping down labour costs for ditching and excavation at the well. Had I not spent all my time on this work costs would have doubled what they are as the men had to dig through hard pan and plenty of rock to put through the ditch. Total labour costs for this work being $74.25. Plumbing costs are $124.14, which includes bridge toll and the services of Garnet Clark, welder.

I might mention that the casing of this artesian well was only 5" and not 6" as expected. It being impossible to place two 1½" check valves in such a small space regardless of the type of valve. Sensing that we would encounter great difficulty there, I made a test of the water rise and got well below the level. Mr. Clark burned through the casing and we set in our pipe and then welded around the casing. During this process the water had to be kept pumped out of the casing. A check (horizontal) valve was placed outside the casing and if anything should ever go wrong with this valve it will not be necessary to touch the regular pump. Incidentally the check valve had to be removed from the regular pump at the well as it was not possible to even get it down past the other piping despite the fact that the casing was hugged.

Both the pump at the school and in the residence are now in good working order and with plenty of water.

...p...t...c
I feel, however, that consideration should be given to the purchase of a gas operated pump for the teachers' residence. The hand pump that is in operation at the present time is somewhat of a man-killer. You must realize that with four people in a house continually there is a lot of water used and with the small pressure tank it has to be pumped at least five times daily. Pumping is comparatively easy until the pressure reaches 30 lbs., beyond that it is no easy job and we cannot expect to have a janitor that receives only $5.00 per month spend all his time pumping water. I would judge that at least two and one-half hours must be spent daily in pumping water by hand and after that is done a janitor has to go about his other work. If we had a gas operated pump there would still be the same pumping to be done but would give a janitor a chance to do his other work while the pump was operating. I discussed the prospect of getting a gas operated pump with Mr. Parker and he advises that there is a possibility but not until August.

T.L. Bonnah
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, June 28, 1944.

Reference to yours of June 1st, re heating of teachers' residence in this village.

Mr. Parker has examined the furnace and taken necessary measurements of the various rooms to ascertain the heating capacity. Considerable repair will be necessary to put the old furnace in good order but Mr. Parker does not recommend that this be undertaken insomuch as even when the furnace was new it did not heat the place. He recommends the purchase of a new furnace and suggests the Beach Air Warmer #24, weight 1600 lbs. with a capacity of 30,000 cu ft. Further, some changes will have to be made in the heating and cold air ducts as is presently located. An additional hot air duct 4 x 6 will have to be installed for upstairs heating and two hot air registers put in the floor downstairs. It appears that apart from the present furnace, which never did work satisfactorily, cold air ducts were not installed in the proper locations downstairs. Doors are being installed in the archways in the dining room and the living room and this won't help matters either unless consideration is given to a larger furnace as specified above. In fact, with the present furnace, even if repaired, will not make the residence bearable should we have a cold winter as it was very difficult to get any heat last winter and the weather was comparatively mild throughout.

I understand from Mr. Parker that the type of furnace above noted could be installed for about $404.00 with the necessary alterations and additional ducts included in this cost.

Would you kindly advise your wishes in this respect.

T. H. Bonnah
Indian Agent.

REPORT ON ST. REGIS INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JUNE, 1944.

Considerable work is being carried on at the teachers' residence in the village. The exterior of the building is receiving a complete paint job. The building in general, over a number of years, has taken terrific punishment due to the fact that rain has been seeping in around the windows and doors and underneath the shingles on the wall of the building resulting in considerable damage being done to the interior. Much of this nuisance has been eliminated now. The roof of the building appears to be in fair condition but it was noted that a 2" gap existed across the entire peak of the roof due to deterioration of the original peak boards. The chimneys at both ends of the building had to be caulked from bottom to top as there was about ½" space open to the elements on each side of the chimney.

A water system was connected up during the month now giving a steady water supply to the residence from the artesian well in the school yard. Unfortunately, however, the old hand pump in the basement which was previously used and hooked up on the present system is definitely not giving service, and an adjustment will have to be made.

Enclosed please find credit voucher No. 171, also supporting pay-lists showing expenditures in connection with painting the exterior of the teachers' residence, St. Regis Village and the decorating of the interior of the Cornwall Island East Day School.

Memorandum

Dr. H.W. McGill

We received in this morning's mail a quotation from Edward Parker, 332 Pitt St., Cornwall, Ontario, on furnace for the St. Regis Village Teachers' residence. His price of $405.00 includes the following:

1. Supplying one #26 Beach Maple Leaf pipe furnace
2. New piping
3. Additional warm air registers
4. Connect present range boiler to furnace with new domestic heater inside the furnace
5. Install the above

As the above price appears to be rather high, I would suggest that to facilitate early placing of order, Mr. Bonnah be instructed:

(a) To obtain at least one competitive price on similar equipment supplied and installed. This quotation may be secured from Albert A. Doyon, 46 Marlborough St., Cornwall, or elsewhere. The tender should indicate the break-up for equipment and labour.

(b) To ascertain from Mr. Parker the price he is quoting for the #26 Beach Maple Leaf furnace complete with casing and top, with separate figures for labour and rate per hour.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

Indian Agent Bonnah phoned from St. Regis to say that the sewage system has completely given out at the St. Regis Village teacher's residence. It will probably be necessary to install a new septic tank. This matter requires immediate attention and Indian Agent Bonnah was authorized to proceed with the necessary work. The probable expenditure will be $200.00.

Ottawa, March 20, 1945.
St. Regis, Que.
March 20, 1945

Philip Phelan, Esq., Chief, Training Division

With reference to our telephone conversation of this date regarding the sewage disposal system at the teachers' residence in the village, I would advise as follows:

The situation at the teachers' residence is similar to what we have experienced here at the office for the past number of years. The cellar drain and the toilets at the residence are on the same hook-up and, with the disposal system seven feet underground, there is very little chance for any seepage. In order to lower the water level in the basement of the residence, and get rid of raw sewage, digging is under way so that we can open up the line to the cesspool. As advised, arrangements have been made to put in a separate system to take care of the first and second floor. A septic tank will be installed near the residence with sufficient seepage lines therefrom to take care of seven people. A cut-off will be made in the cellar approximately eighteen inches below ground level, and hooked up to the new septic tank. In this way, the seepage lines coming from the septic tank will not be buried underground too deeply, where they are of no use. In the meantime, all we can do is keep the old line open to the cesspool, and after the new system is installed, use the old line for a cellar drain only. With more occupants in the residence, and the latter in use the year 'round, it is well to have a system that will give satisfaction. Unfortunately, there is so little land there that the seepage lines will have to be run on a neighbor's property.

Indian Agent

With reference to repairs and redecorating of the various schools and residences at this agency, I may say that (refer your 33-6-8, June 27/45) cost of putting on V-lap was prohibitive due to condition of plaster wall. To go ahead and V-lap this building would mean we would have no funds left for other repairs.

I was fortunate in getting an expert plasterer and had the Teacher's residence and village school and Cornwall Island West School replastered where needed at a cost of $74.15 for labour for this work. I am redecorating the interior of the C. Ild. W. school by Indian labour and also the teachers' residence in the Village. As soon as we can get around to it, the Jr. room of the Village school will be redecorated. The redecorating of course applies only to plastered walls. These walls are being done over with Durolane which is an oil bound paint which I am obtaining from approved sources at a cost of $1.00 per 5-lb. tin.

As requested, both porches have been repaired at the C. Ild. W. school and new woodwork repainted. Work done here will give the interior of this building a cleaner appearance, and will undoubtedly have a good effect on the teacher and pupils.

The attached account in favour of Albert A. Doyon in the amount of $34.00 is for plumbing done at the Teacher's Residence, St. Regis Village School.

The cast iron pipe going through the cement wall was sheared completely off thus blocking the entire sewage system. I have consulted various persons on the cause of this but without much success. The only reason I can give for such a freak break is because the soil being so sandy around the residence and with nearly three months of continuous rainfall, either the building itself settled or the ground around the residence dropped with the weight of water content shearing off the pipe where it comes through the wall.

Re: Insulation, Teachers' Residence, St. Regis Village.

An examination of the above residence discloses that no insulation ever was put in the walls or attic of this building. Further, no louvers were put in the attic. As you know, in past years considerable difficulty was experienced in trying to heat this building. The Adirondack Home Insulation Company of Malone was doing some work here on Indian homes and I asked the representative to give me an estimate on the cost of insulating the teachers' residence.

You will note from the attached that the entire building can be insulated at a cost of $682.00. You will also observe that the attic and dormer can be insulated at a cost of $284.54 along with the installation of vents or louvers. If only the walls of the building are insulated, the cost would be $403.92.

In the event that your office would consider insulating this building, I am forwarding this information on to you as we have found that since we had the Agency Office insulated it has made not only the office but the R.C.M.P. living quarters upstairs livable in winter and summer.

T. L. Hannah,
Superintendent,
St. Regis Agency.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

Referring to your file 42033-2(E), January 24th, re oil storage tank, Sisters' residence, St. Regis, please find enclosed a copy of our letter to your office of November 30th last.

Since our letter of November 30th last, the installation has been completed at the Chenail School residence by installing burners in the old kitchen stove and putting in a coil for a hot water tank. The unit has been working very satisfactory. When we discussed on the telephone, prior to my letter of November 30th last, what disposal would be made of the electric oil burning unit previously purchased for the Chenail School Residence, the suggestion was put forward about transferring that unit to the Sisters' residence in the Village where the power is hooked up and can be operated. The storage tank that came at the time the new electric oil burning unit was received has been set up and will be left at the Chenail School to take care of our oil storage for the nonelectric oil burning unit mentioned above. This brings us to the point that if we transfer to the Sisters' residence the original electric oil burning unit previously purchased for the Chenail School, then we will also have to purchase a storage tank and place it at the Sisters' residence in the village.

As you had not continued further in this matter, I thought possibly you might be pondering over the idea of purchasing an electric stove for the Sisters' residence at St. Regis Village and using the electric oil burning unit at another location where power is available and heating is essential from a kitchen stove. In the Sisters' residence, of course, there is a large furnace which gives adequate heat and an electric stove definitely would be more practical there. If you decide on the electric stove for the Sisters' residence we will not require the oil storage tank. Please advise.

(Sgd) T. L. Bonnah,
Superintendent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

Some months ago I discussed with Mr. A. J. Doucet the possibility of obtaining the services of a young man from the Cornwall Island Reserve who had recently been discharged from the United States Army. It was suggested at that time that he be placed in charge of Manual Training classes in our various schools and at the same time take over the boys' work which I had started. The name of this young man I had in mind was Ernest Benedict and after explaining everything to Mr. Doucet it was agreed that we can obtain his services and could put him on at a rate of around $1,500.00 per annum. Due to various reasons of which perhaps army life may have been responsible, it was not possible to get Ernie to settle down and after considering every angle I thought it better to let the matter rest in abeyance until he was prepared to readjust himself to civilian life.

Some days ago he contacted me and advised that, if given the opportunity, he was prepared to go to work in the capacity previously outlined to him and I am pleased, therefore, to forward his application with the hope that your office may see fit to consider his appointment. It is true he would have very little to work with insofar as manual training is concerned. It may also be true that travelling will present some obstacle during the winter months. I do not feel, however, that such obstacles should prevent the employment of this man as I know him to be quite capable and could be depended upon in lieu of regular manual training (equipment which we have not on hand) to keep the boys occupied in such work as leathercraft, beadwork, wood carving, and basketry. There is plenty of work for him to do in this regard and I feel confident that if he is employed we can get together and work out a very good program for the benefit of all concerned.

May I hear from you in the above respect at an early date or if it is possible for Mr. Doucet to pay us a visit, so much the better.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

In connection with Home Economics at the St. Regis Village School, I would advise that it is very difficult to carry out a full program due to the fact that it is impossible to obtain sufficient sugar coupons. While every precaution is exercised by the Sister in charge to see that only such dishes are prepared that require a minimum of sugar, she finds it very difficult to carry through this program on account of the lack of this commodity.

Would it be possible to obtain and forward us sufficient sugar coupons to purchase approximately 20 pounds of sugar to cover our requirements for the balance of the year in this respect.

T. L. Bonnah,
Indian Agent.

TLB:SS
Ottawa, 4 December 1946.

Mr. T.L. Bonnah, Indian Agent,
P.O. Box 987, CORNWALL, Ontario.

We have your letter of the 28th ultimo with reference to securing sugar coupons to enable you to purchase 20 pounds of sugar for the Home Economics class at the St. Regis Village School.

We can arrange to secure the coupons for you but it will be necessary for us to know the name and address of the firm from whom the sugar will be purchased and the coupons will be sent direct to them.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

Referring to your letter of the 4th instant, the name of the business firm we will purchase the sugar from is known as:

Forget & McCabe,
59 Pitt Street,
Cornwall, Ontario.

Please forward coupons for 20 pounds of sugar to the above firm.

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

TLB:SS
Ottawa, December 13th, 1946.

Mr. T. L. Bonnah,
Indian Agent, St. Regis, P.Q.,
P.O. Box 987, Cornwall, Ont.

As requested in your letter dated December 10th, we enclose herewith a sugar ration cheque for twenty coupons in favour of Forget & McCabe, 59 Pitt St., Cornwall, Ontario.

Encl.

G. Armstrong,
Welfare Division.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,

Dear Sir,

In answer to your letter of Dec. 15, 1931 NO.68-1-1 about the day school, I beg to inform you that I recommend this school be closed for the following reasons: it is impossible to keep a day school on the Reserve with an Indian girl as teacher because the parents of the children are jealous, they all want that the teacher should be their daughter. They all want to let their house for the school.

It is too bad that I could not make any arrangement with the Municipality Of Seven-Islands to take back these children to their school as before.

I have not the same trouble at Moisie as The Municipality want still take our Indians at their school.

I thought that by refusing to give any relief to those who would not go to the school I would have success but I was deceived.

The only thing I have to do now, is to make arrangement for the Indians who really desire their children be educated to send them to Moisie school.

Ottawa, January 12, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, recommending that the school at Seven Islands be closed on account of poor attendance and local jealousies among the Indian parents.

In reply I have to say it is considered that this school has not been a success from the point of attendance and that it would be a waste of money to continue it in operation. You will, therefore, be good enough to inform the teacher that this school is to be closed at the end of the present month and that her services will not be required after that date. She should prepare a return showing the attendance and days taught during the current month and forward same to the Department through your office, when payment of any salary due her to the date the school closed will be made. It is noted that you will endeavour to make arrangements with the Moisie White School for the attendance of the Indian children whose parents desire them to attend. It is hoped that the majority of the parents will agree to allow their children to attend school at Moisie.

Ottawa, July 18, 1945.

Dr. Gerard Beaulieu, Indian Agent,
Seven Islands, Can. Labrador, Que.

Chief Andre and some other Indians from Seven Islands visited the Department recently and requested the establishment of schools. He claimed that there were approximately 150 children between 7 and 16 years of age, for whom no educational facilities are available.

As you are probably aware, we operated a school for several years at Seven Islands, but, owing to irregular attendance, it was closed in January, 1932, and we have never re-opened it.

Is there any building available for school purposes? How many children do you think would attend if a school was opened?

They also made a request to have Jovite Andre sent to Rivere du Loup Convent. It was stated that it would involve an expenditure of $180.00 for one year. Please let me have your views regarding this request.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Seven Islands July 23, 1945,

Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa,

In answer to Mr. Phelan's letter of July 18, 1945, regarding education of Indian children, we would be able to have a class room for school purposes in the new building bought recently from the Hudson's Bay Co. Further details may be obtained from Mr. Thibault who inspected this building on his recent inspection tour.

As most families go hunting during the winter months, it would be advisable to have school during the summer, that is from March to October. During this time about 100 children would be able to attend, but in Moisie the Indian children could attend the white school, as was done in previous years at a rate of $15.00 a year per pupil.

Regarding Jovite Andre, the Chief's daughter, who wishes to go to the convent at Riviere du Loup, I would suggest she attend school here for at least a year because she is 13 years old and has never been to school.

The Chief came here, and informed me that he already had authorization from you to send his daughter to the convent, if this is so, you will have several more similar requests as all the Indians would like to send their children out, providing the Department is willing to pay.

The Chief Andre would like an immediate answer as he leaves for his hunting grounds in August.

Dr. G. Beaulieu, Indian Agent,

March 19th., 1949.

Inspector of Indians,

We are Indians living on the Reserve and we write to tell you that we have lost our good school teacher, Miss Hélène Jourdain who had been teaching our children for a long time. She left because she would not accept pupils from outside the Reserve, which would have spoiled the classes of our children; the children of Mr. Francisse Pinette, a settler of Baie des Sept-Îles, who now resides at Sept Îles outside the Reserve. The Indians asked politely to Mr. Pauzé, the Agent, to refuse to accept these children who are not on the Reserve, so the classes would not be disturbed before the end of the year. Mr. Pauzé did not agree. We also asked him to wait for the visit of the Inspector of Indians, this summer, so he could discuss with him the question of that family who never resided on the Reserve, but he positively refused.

Miss Hélène Jourdain who was unwilling to accept the children of Mr. Pinette left her class, to avoid having trouble with these children, and Mr. Pauzé asked Mrs. Johnny Noel to replace Miss Hélène Jourdain. The Indians do not like to send their children to Mrs. Johnny Noel, they prefer to send them to Miss Hélène Jourdain. The latter has a private school at her home and has 12 pupils.

Is it fair to disturb our class in that way for the sake of disturbing intruders, and we ask you to treat us with justice.

Thanking you in anticipation, I am,

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) Sylvestre Meckenzie.

As requested in your last letter, I wish to inform you that Mrs Marie Anne Noel is a full time teacher. She is teaching from 09:00 A.M. till 11:30 A.M. and from 01:00 P.M. till 04:00 P.M.

Before discussing the content of Mrs Pierre Vachon's telegram I wish to inform you that she is a well known troublemaker, she has been that way for years and will always be looking for trouble.

As for the content of the telegram I wish to advise that Mrs Pierre Vachon is trying to avenge herself of an old feud against Mrs Noel and Mrs Noel's mother (all Indian women). Referring to some old records I found out that Mrs Pierre Vachon was arraigned in court on October 26, 1931 for having stolen from Mrs Noel's mother a kettle and a half moose skin, and was found guilty by the Justice of the Peace Dr. J.H. Lavallee, ex-Indian Agent. This same year Mrs Noel was teaching school and a daughter of Mrs Pierre Vachon happened to be one of her pupils. Apparently the said pupil attacked Mrs Noel in school with a heavy wooden pencil box. No need to tell you that the school teacher Mrs Noel tried to take that pencil box off the assailant's hands. While they were both pulling on the wooden pencil box it slipped off the school teacher's hands and the pupil struck herself on the arm and made a king of a bruise, it was also reported to me that in striking some muscles her arm was swollen the next day. This was the only time Mrs Noel had anything that went wrong with her pupils and most likely what Mrs Vachon is referring in her telegram when he states: THE
LATTER (Mrs Noel) ALREADY MADE ONE BAD BREAK BY HURTING A (should have been "her") CHILD.

2.- "WE HAVE LOST OUR GOOD TEACHER WHO HAD TAUGHT OUR CHILDREN FOR ELEVEN YEARS." From what I gathered if we take off from that eleven years the days she was sick and the days when she did not feel like teaching her full time teaching would be worth about 4 or 5 years.

3.- As for the part: "THE PRIEST CONSIDERED THAT SHE SHOULD NEVER TEACH THEREAFTER...", I doubt very much such statement as Mrs Noel went on teaching till the end of the school year. Furthermore I cannot find in our records a report or a judicial record against Mrs Noel. Unhappily the Priest in question left Seven Islands 15 or 16 years ago.

4.- MORE THAN HALF THE CHILDREN HAVE QUIT ATTENDING..."

A wrong statement again approximately 1/3 of Miss Helen Jourdain's pupils and approximately 1/6 of the of the Seven Islands Indian Day School attendance have left the school.

Referring to Family Allowance problem I regret to inform you that I reported to the Regional Director of Family Allowances the children mentioned in my letter of March 9, 1949. I waited till March 19, 1949, to hear from you but unhappily your letter reached me on March 25, 1949. The reason is that I had to set them an example (cancellation of their Family Allowances cheques for April) so as to counteract a certain propaganda started by them, the last two weeks, to get some of our pupils out of Mrs Noel's division, so as to enlist more pupils in Miss Jourdain's private course, who by the way is teaching only two (2) hours per day which is far from being efficient. We cannot let them win their points it would be too bad for the future of our school teachers and of our schools of Moisie and Seven Islands.

J. M. Pauze
Supt., Indian Agency,
Seven Islands, Que.

Enforcement of the Indian Act (Sec. 10)
Seven Islands Reserve.

1. Following a series of events which brought about the dismissal of Miss Helene JOURDAIN (Indian) as school teacher at the local Indian school on March 3rd, 1945 several Indian parents whose children were in Miss JOURDAIN's class, withdrew their children from the Indian school and sent them to a private school opened by Miss JOURDAIN. The reason for this was that these Indians objected to Miss JOURDAIN's substitute, Mrs. Johnny NOEL (Indian).

2. Mr. M. PAUSE, superintendent of the Seven Islands Indian Agency made every effort to deal with the matter as tactfully as possible and have the parents send their children to the Indian Day-Time School; and in the light of the continuous refusal he reported these children as being absent from school to the Family Allowances Board in Quebec City who in turn deprived the parents of the Family Allowances for these children, 12 altogether. Furthermore, Mr. Pause has requested the assistance of the undersigned to enforce Sec. 10 of the Indian Act.

3. Miss JOURDAIN though she has been teaching on and off for the past 12 years for the Dept. of Indian Affairs, is not a qualified teacher, whilst Mrs. Noel on the other hand possesses the proper qualifications. Furthermore Miss JOURDAIN only teaches from 1.00 p.m. to 2.30 p.m. and from 3.45 p.m. to 5.45 p.m., whilst the Indians attending the Indian Day-Time School have to go to school from 8.00 a.m. to 12.00 noon and from 1.30 p.m. to 4.00 p.m. As a result of the difference in school hours, the children from the Indian school are frequently tempted not to go to school in the forenoon.

4. The writer concurs with the Indian Agent and Indian Chief's opinion that the idea of the private school has an ill-effect on Indians of the Seven Islands Reserve. Furthermore, since Miss JOURDAIN was considered an incompetent teacher and showed a definite lack of knowledge of the French language (which is taught at the Indian School) it is felt that some action should be taken to prevent her from teaching at a private school. It may also be pointed out that Miss JOURDAIN and the parents do favour her teaching, are all followers of SIOUX and do not hesitate to cause dissension amongst Indians whenever possible.

5. The writer is of the opinion that a strict application of Sec. 10, as 3 & 4, upon children and parents who support Miss JOURDAIN would prove satisfactory. Your further instructions in this connection will be awaited.

MEMORANDUM.

To Deputy Minister

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, 2nd Sept. 1893

With reference to Constable Miller's letter of the 21st last reporting on the condition of the Dennis Cameron School under the new teacher Miss Legge I beg to state that the report is very satisfactory to teachers evidently doing her utmost to bring the school up to a high state of efficiency. She reports however on a matter which calls for some action on the part of the office. He states that there are a good many children attending the school who do not belong to it, that they come from the townships of Craig & that some are white cross from part Indians. He says they have their own school where they can attend also that they do not attend the Indians' School. I am unable to tell the number of Indian children attending at the school as the new teacher has not returned to office. Mr. Miller does not give the number of outside children attending but if he does it will be necessary to take steps to prevent them from attending.
MEMORANDUM.

To Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, 189—

Teachers can teach the Indians in addition to the Indian children without any detriment to the latter. I think they ought be allowed to attend by paying say 50 cents per month. Before anything further is done in the matter however I would recommend that Mr. Miller be requested to give the names of the outside children attending, and also their reason for attending the Indian School in preference to their own school. And in the event of their being attended by the DIAH to attend the school whether the teacher cared to teach them without any loss to the Indian children.

John M[il]ler

In a Temiscamingue School.

On my visit to the Indian Reserve at Temiscamingue, I called at the school and found it neat and clean, the children well dressed and many of them are bright and intelligent looking.

I examined the classes and was surprised to find such progress among the more advanced pupils. The teacher, Miss Legge, appears to have the confidence of pupils and parents, and from what I saw she deserves it.

I have to inform you that sometime ago Mr. E. H. Morcom brought a sentimental letter to me which assured him that he might send his children to the Indian School here provided he paid a fee of $50 each. I was not aware of any child being there without the consent of their parents.

Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, 4th June, 1900.

The Secretary:

Mr Agent Burwash reported in March last that the eyesight of the teacher of the Temiscamingue school was failing and he was asked to report whether her infirmity interfered with the discipline and progress of the pupils. In reply he stated that it did so very seriously and that the pupils spent considerable of their time in school hours playing apparently without being seen by the teacher, whom they treat with very little respect, usually speaking to and of her as "Fannie".

Dear Sir,

At the desire of the Band and owing to the importance of the matter, I beg leave to offer you as clear and full an explanation as I can in writing of our reasons of being desirous to have the Grey Nuns reside here as teachers for our children and nurses for our sick and old people.

First: It is well known to us from long experience that the Sisters are the best teachers for children in a mixed population as we have on this reserve. Also the Sisters are usually skilled in medicine. Their advice would be of value to us, whether cases in sickness were serious or not.

Secondly: We have strong reasons for wishing a change in our school, as there has been a very small attendance of our children for some time and I believe there is good reasons for it,-in fact too many reasons to mention in writing.

Sir,

In reply to your favor of 28th Nov. last in connection with a report that some half breed children were excluded from attending Indian school.

I beg to state that the above statement is rather misleading. Half breed children although not members of the band have never been excluded from the Indian school, some have been attending all along. The band did ask twenty-five cents per month for each child that attended school, if the parents that could afford it, to help pay for firewood and keep the school clean and in repair, but none ever responded, but the children were not stopped from attending school. The party referred to in Rev. Luther King's letter is Robert King, he is a brother of the present chief. I spoke to the chief about the matter, he says his brother's children were never prevented by himself or the band from attending the Indian school.

There was another school for a short while for white children but owing to illness of teacher, it is now closed.

It is only since the beginning of the present term that white children have been excluded from the Indian school, and the reason that they were, was because the parents were not willing to do what was fair and right, they did not pay for the privilege.

The Secretary

Sir,

I beg to report that I have recently visited the Indian day school on North Temiscaming Reserve.

This school is at present in charge of the Rev. Sister Monica. In many ways, worthy of mention, the school impressed me very favourably. The pupils were all clean and the order kept was good. The attendance was fair. School supplies etc., are kept in very good condition and the building itself was clean.

I heard two of the classes, one in arithmetic and another in reading and dictation. I also examined the work done at the desks. Some of the work was very creditable but of course I am not in a position to give any opinion as to progress. What I saw might have been taught and learned by the pupils, this year or last year. The class in arithmetic was of the younger pupils and while I may not be competent to express an opinion as to teaching methods, not being a school inspector, Sister Monica's method with the class in arithmetic certainly struck me as being far from practical.

I noticed that she spoke with a distinct French accent, if the term may be used, and did not appear to readily understand.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent,
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
understand some questions I asked her. A lack of pronunciation of the Rs was particularly noticeable. For her own purposes, however, she has quite good command of English; that is for conversational purposes. If asked to express an opinion as to her suitability for teaching English I would from my own viewpoint put it this way:- Reversing conditions; if I were studying French I would certainly want one whose pronunciation of French was better than her pronunciation of English. This may be a somewhat indirect method of arriving at a conclusion and yet it is to me the only standpoint from which I could express an opinion having in mind my lack of qualification as a school inspector.

I noticed that the stove in the school building is old and badly cracked and standing on the bare, dry, soft wood floor. I advised the agent to ask permission to purchase a new stove and a zinc floor tray on which to stand it. The present outfit is a fire menace.

I would also suggest that the building will require painting inside, next spring and that a lighter color be used on the walls and ceiling.

Your obedient servant,

I beg to say that I visited the day school on the North Temiskaming reserve, during my recent inspection trip in that locality.

I cannot say that I was impressed with the progress made by the pupils. I am also still of the opinion that the teacher's methods are not as modern as they might be. I had the same classes up before me as on my previous visit last fall. I failed to see any improvement. This was particularly noticeable in the junior class which I heard in addition tables. The reading of the larger pupils was very poor and none of them were able to properly pronounce the th sound, as in mother. The teacher was also cut on this sound until I started to call the attention of the pupils to it.

Dear Sir,

I take the liberty of writing these few lines to you as the School Teacher of the Indian School at North Temiskaming. We have had an epidemic of Diphtheria among the Indians here for the last 2 months and a half and the attendance has been very small at the school, and quite a few of the families have moved into the bush for the winter months.

Now we propose to close the school until the first of April 1918 as there is not an attendance large enough to occupy the time of the teacher as there are only 3 or 4 pupils going to the school. We would like very much to have the same teacher come back again as she gives the best of satisfaction.

In order to do this we would like to have her salary paid during the time the school is closed as she gave up her allotee below to come up here.

Hoping you will give this a favorable consideration I am the

Yours very truly,

John Geo. McBride
Chief

Madam,
